ratings.comment: My guess was he was overwhelmed with courses (having said he was teaching 6 studio courses). I was told that exam answers had to be quoted from his lecture slides to receive full points. Not only that but remembering all that information for 20+ art works wasn't my strong suit. Grading was tough, yet the workload is small.
Very hard grader and lots of work, but you learn a lot and he is very knowledgable about Graphic Design.
Horrible professor with no positive criticism. He is blatantly rude and harasses his students.

He's knowledgeable and passionate about graphic design, but he's very unpleasant to interact with. Felt like I was interacting with a 5 year old who was trying to win a fight while asking him about assignments and grading. He does petty things and uses his power as a professor to ensure you can't question his actions as a rude belittling person.

He's highly qualified and knows his stuff. However, the class was miserable because he is unnecessarily strict, inflexible, and sometimes rude. The lectures are long and dry, and he expects you to memorize dozens of artists/titles for every "quiz", which are mini exams. Work hard and get on his good side early on to make the semester more tolerable

I absolutely loved the history of graphic design online. His structure was easy to follow and the work was manageable. You have to get your work in on time but he does not grade difficulty. His passion for graphic design is abundant and his lectures always left me inspired and looking at more graphic inspiration.
Does not accommodate. Very brash and unwilling to take responsibility for his arrogant mistakes. Does not listen or take to criticism well.
Lectures are over the top long and boring. Tests are hard, he is cold and inflexible.

I really enjoyed this class Professor Miller asks a lot from his students but in return he is a passionate teacher and made me enjoy the material. I took this class last semester yes the work ramps up towards the end of the semester however the work is manageable and worth the class
Really bad

One of the worst class I have EVER taken so far. His lectures are extremely boring, reading 300+ slides in the 1.5hr lectures. Weekly essays + 5000 WORDS research paper. The exams are ridiculous and he expects everyone to memorize more than 100 artifacts. Do Not Take His Class!!

He reads off the lecture slides. He reads at one hundred miles per hour, and is constantly jumbling his words because he is trying to get through *hundreds of lecture slides per lecture*. He goes through literally 300+ slides in 1.5 hrs. Don't think you'll get any other work done in class either, no phones or laptops or you'll lose a letter grade.

If you are passionate about graphic design and willing to work hard for it, you will have no problem working with him. He is harsh and very strange so it takes some time to get used to his teaching methods. He is often unnecessarily harsh at first, so be prepared. Once you get past that, he is an awesome professor with a lot of talent.

He's a great designer and a helpful professor. However, he NEVER emails back which is extremely frustrating and should not be an issue for a professor. Overall I would recommend any of his classes, as long as you are prepared to work.

Dennis Miller will prepare you for brand design in the real world. Expect to do a lot of research prior to designing anything and expect harsh criticism of your work. This does not make him a bad teacher. He is trying to prepare you for what a career in design is like in the real world. He will not hesitate to rip your work apart of it is not good.
One of the hardest classes I've evert taken, but also one the best. The professor was prepared, efficient, and always tried to give the clearest possible feedback.

This professor constantly pushed us and made us work hard, but his attitude was not appropriate for the classroom. He belittled us publicly at times and critical in a negative way. He has a controlling personality which really did not make for a positive learning environment. He's a fine designer - just maybe not the best person to teach it.

This version of the course is about typeface design. The structure was clear, and feedback was both timely and helpful. Makes surprising connections between traditional drawing and digital media. Best course I've taken on advanced level in the department. This is the guy that SHOULD be teaching the advanced graphic design classes!

dennis is a great professor with a lot of expectations-- which is good. you learn a lot, and always follow his design rules and suggestions. he knows what he's talking about. best art professor i've had, because i was challenged.

most of the comments here are unfair. professor miller is passionate about what he teaches, and he expects a lot out of you. his class isn't a blow off class like the other courses in the art department. he just wants you to think AND work hard. his class is beneficial if you give it a chance.

Apparently Dennis was almost fired for being too mean so now he is nicer? I believe it. His personality takes a little getting used to but he has good intentions & he actually cares. If you follow his design "rules" you will be fine. He sends out emails with assignment reminders after each class which is super helpful. Overall I enjoyed this class!

He was a very hard professor, he was rude and made my last semester hell.  I really don't like his attitude and how OCD he is.  He is a hard grader and makes you feel stupid at times.  He gave me the worst grade that I have received even with all the work that I put in, making me question if I should be in this career field.  I would NOT recommend.

Tons and tons of work. This class is no joke, so be ready to pull some all nighters. Dennis at first might be a little harsh at times but, he tries to get the best out of you each day in and day out. If you want to produce great work, this is the class to be in. Just try to understand his personality and stick with it he is only trying to help.
really hard. alot of work. great crits. don't get behind on the projects because it's kind of hard to get caught up.
